results.brief_description: A time sequence of the fires that swept South Australia and Victria on Ash Wednesday, 16 February 1983, as depicted through news broadcasts. No other credits available.

results.title: From the ashes of war
results.creator_credit: Michael McKennirey, Nico Crama, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film uses stock shots, photographs, and rare archival film footage to document the liberation of Amsterdam by Canadian troops in May, 1945, and the events preceding it. Some of the worst battles, such as the Battle of the Scheldt and the crossing of the Leopold Canal, are shown. The film is narrated by Alex Colville, internationally known painter, who was an official war artist at the time. The film captures the horror of a people at war and testifies to the strong friendship that developed between Holland and Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael McKennirey, Nico Crama, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: From the ashes
results.creator_credit: Helena Solberg Ladd, Glenn Silber and International Women's Film Project Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary tracing the history of Nicaragua from the presence of U.S. Marines in the early 1900s, through several rebellions to the problems of the present (up to 1981). The film focuses on the present efforts of the people to rebuild their country. Includes interviews.

results.title: From sociable six to noisy nine [col]
results.creator_credit: Judith Crawley, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The film looks into the meaning of various forms of conduct in children from six to nine years and suggests ways in which parents may guide them through a challenging, often trying phase of development. In a family with three children we observe how the parents cope with often baffling situations.

results.title: From silence to speech
results.brief_description: Training children to speak in Victorian institutions for the education of the deaf. It is essential that deaf children begin education early, and at the Princess Elizabeth Kindergarten, children are taught to lipread in order to associate lip movements with vocal sounds. As they grow older, children continue to the Victorian School for Deaf Children where they continue speech training, commence primary education, play games, learn handcrafts, carpentry and domestic training.

results.title: From school to work bench
results.brief_description: The training of the future skilled workers of West Germany. At the end of an elementary school education boys and girls are tested by vocational guidance experts; visits to factories, agricultural schools, business and domestic science colleges etc give an insight into the demands and qualifications required for the many skilled crafts and the simplest professions of this modern age.

results.title: From sand to celluloid (A)
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
